tit.cmt: 括弧内を小文字にしました。

sen.j: 姓（カバネ）とは、古代日本のヤマト王権において、大王 (ヤマト王権)（おおきみ）から有力な氏族に与えられた、王権との関係・地位を示す称号である。
sen.e: Kabane (hereditary title) were titles given from Great King to powerful families which showed ones' relationships to the sovereignty as well as ones' ranks within Yamato sovereignty of ancient Japan.

Kabane refers to the titles given by Okimi (great king) (Yamato sovereignty) to powerful clans which showed ones' relationships to the sovereignty as well as ones' ranks in the Yamato sovereignty of ancient Japan.
sen.cmt: 一部表現を変更しました。
sen.e: Kabane refers to the titles given by Okimi (great king) (Yamato sovereignty) to powerful clans which showed ones' relationships to the sovereignty as well as ones' ranks in the Yamato sovereignty of ancient Japan.

sen.j: その発祥の経緯は明確ではない。
sen.e: It is unknow how they were originated.
It is unknown how they were originated.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。
sen.e: It is unknown how they were originated.

sen.j: ヤマト王権が成熟し、大王家を中心として有力氏族の職掌や立場が次第に確定していく中で、各有力者の職掌や地位を明示するために付与されたと考えられている。
sen.e: It is believed that they were given to powerful clans to show their ranks and official duties as they began solidifying their positions in relation to Rotal Family when Yamato sovereignty became stable.

It is believed that they were given to powerful clans to show their ranks and official duties as they began solidifying their positions in relation to Royal Family when Yamato sovereignty became stable.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。
sen.e: It is believed that they were given to powerful clans to show their ranks and official duties as they began solidifying their positions in relation to Royal Family when Yamato sovereignty became stable.

sen.j: 職掌を示す姓（カバネ）としては、国造（くにのみやつこ）、県主（あがたのぬし）、稲置(いなぎ)などがある。
sen.e: Kabane which denoted official duties included kuni no miyatsuko (the heads of local governments), Ataganushi (territorial ruler) and inagi.
Kabane which denoted official duties included kuni no miyatsuko (the heads of local governments), Ataganushi (territorial ruler) and inagi.
Kabane which denoted official duties included kuni no miyatsuko (the heads of local governments), Ataganushi (territorial ruler) and inagi.

sen.j: 地位・格式・立場を示す姓（カバネ）としては、公（きみ）、臣（おみ）、連（むらじ）、造(みやつこ)、直（あたい）、首(おびと)、史（ふひと）、村主（すぐり）などがある。
sen.e: Kabane which denoted ranks, social statuses and positions included kimi, omi, muraji, miyatsuko, atai, obito, fuhito and suguri.
Kabane which denoted ranks, social statuses and positions included kimi, omi, muraji, miyatsuko, atai, obito, fuhito and suguri.

sen.j: その他の姓（カバネ）としては、百済滅亡後に亡命してきた百済王族に与えられた百済王氏（こにきし）などがある。
sen.e: Other kabane included konikishi which was given to the Royal Families of Baekje after fleeing to Japan due to the fall of their country.
Other kabane included konikishi which was given to the Royal Families of Baekje after fleeing to Japan due to the fall of their country.

sen.j: 姓（カバネ）の中では、臣、連が一番格式が高いとされ、最も有力な者には更に大臣 (古代日本)（おおおみ）、大連 (古代日本)（おおむらじ）の姓（カバネ）が与えられた。
sen.e: Omi and muraji were thought to be the high ranks within kabane, and the highest ranks given to the most powerful individuals were oomi and omuraji (in ancient Japan).
sen.cmt: 臣と大臣の訳が両方ともomiとなるので大臣はoomiと記しました。
sen.e: Omi and muraji were thought to be the high ranks within kabane, and the highest ranks given to the most powerful individuals were oomi (ancient Japan) and omuraji (ancient Japan).
sen.cmt: 古代日本 を追加しました。
sen.e: Omi and muraji were thought to be the high ranks within kabane, and the highest ranks given to the most powerful individuals were oomi (ancient Japan) and omuraji (ancient Japan).

sen.j: 姓（カバネ）の制度は、壬申の乱（672年）の後、天武天皇が制定した八色の姓によって有名無実化されていき、臣、連ですら序列の6、7番目に位置づけられ、その地位は、実質上、無意味化した。
sen.e: After the Jinshin War (occurred in 672), the kabane system existed in name only when the eight kabane system was installed by the Emperor Tem, which put omi and muraji in 6th and 7th from the top, and thus those titles no longer held any values.

After the Jinshin War (occurred in 672), the kabane system existed in name only when Yakusa no Kabane (the eight honorary titles) system was installed by the Emperor Tenmu, which put omi and muraji in sixth and seventh from the top, and thus those titles no longer held any values.
sen.cmt: 数字をスペルアウトしました。
sen.e: After the Jinshin War (occurred in 672), the kabane system existed in name only when Yakusa no Kabane (the eight honorary titles) system was installed by the Emperor Tenmu, which put omi and muraji in sixth and seventh from the top, and thus those titles no longer held any values.

sen.j: 代わって、天皇への忠誠心がある有能な人材には新たに作られた真人（まひと）・朝臣(あそん）・宿禰(すくね)・忌寸（いみき）の姓（カバネ）が与えられた。
sen.e: Instead, those competent individuals who showed their loyalty to the emperor were given new kabane mahito, ason, sukune and imiki.
Instead, those competent individuals who showed their loyalty to the emperor were given new kabane such as mahito, ason, sukune and imiki.
sen.cmt: such as を追加しました。
sen.e: Instead, those competent individuals who showed their loyalty to the emperor were given new kabane such as mahito, ason, sukune and imiki.

sen.j: しかしながら、奈良時代を過ぎるとほとんどの氏族の姓（カバネ）が朝臣（あそん）になってしまい、八色の姓も甚だ形式的なものに変質してしまう。
sen.e: However, almost all families were granted the kabane ason after Nara Period, and therefore the eight kabane system also lost its meaning and existed in name only.
However, almost all clans were granted the kabane ason after Nara period, and therefore Yakusa no Kabane system also lost its meaning and existed in name only.
sen.cmt: 八色の姓 読みを追加しました。
sen.e: However, almost all clans were granted the kabane ason after Nara period, and therefore Yakusa no Kabane system also lost its meaning and existed in name only.

sen.j: この姓（カバネ）は、後世での扱われ方からヤマト王権当初から氏族単位に賦与（ふよ）されていたと考えられていたが、実証的な文献研究により、ヤマト王権当初の姓（カバネ）は個人単位で付与されていたことが明らかとなったと主張する人がいる。
sen.e: It was believed that the kabane were given to each clan as they were later on, however, based on the research of historical records, some strongly suggests that they were given to individuals in the beginning of Yamato sovereignty.

It was believed that the kabane were given to each clan from the beginning of Yamato sovereignty; however, based on the research of historical records, some strongly suggest that they were given to individuals in the beginning of Yamato sovereignty.
sen.cmt: ヤマト王権当初は を一箇所追加しました。
sen.e: It was believed that the kabane were given to each clan from the beginning of Yamato sovereignty; however, based on the research of historical records, some strongly suggest that they were given to individuals in the beginning of Yamato sovereignty.

sen.j: それは十分考えられることである。
sen.e: There are possibilities that the later theory is correct.
It is highly likely that the latter theory is correct.
sen.cmt: 一部表現を変更しました。
sen.e: It is highly likely that the latter theory is correct.

sen.j: しかし、仮にそうであった場合でも、律令的氏姓制度が形骸化するに連れて、氏（ウヂ）と姓（カバネ）とが世襲化により一体化され、その構成員もいたずらに増え過ぎてしまったため、のちにヤマト王権（天武天皇）自身が八色の姓（やくさのかばね）によって全く新たな官位制度と連動させつつ氏姓の制（うじかばねのせい）を実質的に無意味化せざるを得なかった。
sen.e: However, even if it was the case, Emperor Tenmu had to create the new eight kabane system which resulted the dysfunction of the original kabane system since the kabane were given to too many people, and uji and kabane became integrated through heredity as the system of clans and hereditary titles based on a ritsuryo legal code remained simply as a form.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, even if it was the case, Emperor Tenmu (Yamato sovereignty) had to create the Yakusa no Kabane system which resulted in the dysfunction of the original kabane system since the kabane were given to too many people, and uji and kabane became integrated through heredity as the system of clans and hereditary titles based on a ritsuryo legal code remained simply as a form.
sen.cmt: ヤマト王権 を追加しました。
sen.e: However, even if it was the case, Emperor Tenmu (Yamato sovereignty) had to create the Yakusa no Kabane system which resulted in the dysfunction of the original kabane system since the kabane were given to too many people, and uji and kabane became integrated through heredity as the system of clans and hereditary titles based on a ritsuryo legal code remained simply as a form.

sen.j: しかも、世襲化されている旧来の姓（カバネ）ではなく、全く新たな姓（カバネ）である真人（まひと）・朝臣（あそん）・宿禰(すくね)・忌寸（いみき）を導入し、それらを賦与ないし継承させる氏上（うじのかみ）を直系親族に限定し、その許認可権すら当初は天武天皇自ら握っていたという事実は動かない。
sen.e: Furthermore, the fact that Emperor Tenmu introduced new kabane such as mahito, ason, sukune and imiki rather using the ones that had already been passed on and allowed only a member of an immediate Imperial Family to be in the position of Ujinokami which had the right to give kabane as well as the permission to inherit does not change.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Furthermore, the fact remains that Emperor Tenmu introduced new kabane such as mahito, ason, sukune and imiki rather than using the ones that had already been passed on, that he allowed only the members of an immediate Imperial Family to be in the position of Ujinokami which had the right to give kabane, and that he even had the authority to give permission in the beginning.
sen.cmt: 一部表現を変更しました。
sen.e: Furthermore, the fact remains that Emperor Tenmu introduced new kabane such as mahito, ason, sukune and imiki rather than using the ones that had already been passed on, that he allowed only the members of an immediate Imperial Family to be in the position of Ujinokami which had the right to give kabane, and that he even had the authority to give permission in the beginning.

sen.j: そして、この八色の姓も、天武天皇没後、旧来の氏姓の制と同様に早々に機能不全の道を辿っていく。
sen.e: This eight kabane system stopped functioning like the original kabane system after the death of Emperor Tenmu.
Also, this Yakusa no Kabane system stopped functioning like the original kabane system after the death of Emperor Tenmu.
sen.cmt: 八色の姓 読みを追加しました。
sen.e: Also, this Yakusa no Kabane system stopped functioning like the original kabane system after the death of Emperor Tenmu.

sen.j: ヤマト王権から明治維新までかろうじて命脈を保った姓（カバネ）は、藤原氏永敏（大村益次郎）・藤原朝臣利通（大久保利通）・菅原氏重信（大隈重信）・源氏有朋（山縣有朋‎）などに代表される朝臣、「越智氏博文」（伊藤博文）などに代表される宿禰である。
sen.e: The only kabane that remained from the Yamato sovereignty till the Meiji Restoration were ason and sukune; Nagatoshi from Fujiwara clan (Masujiro OMURA), FUJIWARA no Ason Toshimichi (Toshimichi OKUBO), Shigenobu from Sugawara clan (Shigenobu SUGAWARA) and Aritomo from Minamoto clan (Aritomo AMAGATA) being the examples of ason, and 'Hirobumi from Ochi clan' (Hirobumi ITO) being the example of sukune.

sen.e: The only kabane that remained from the Yamato sovereignty till the Meiji Restoration were ason and sukune; Nagatoshi from Fujiwara clan (Masujiro OMURA), FUJIWARA no Ason Toshimichi (Toshimichi OKUBO), Shigenobu from Sugawara clan (Shigenobu OKUMA) and Aritomo from Minamoto clan (Aritomo YAMAGATA) being the examples of ason, and 'Hirobumi from Ochi clan' (Hirobumi ITO) being the example of sukune.

sen.j: これらの真偽はともかくとして、天皇および朝廷に仕えるために必要不可欠とされた氏（ウヂ）・姓（カバネ）が復古的に用意されただけ、という意味合いが強い。
sen.e: Whether those names were true or not, it is said that uji and kabane were only used since it was necessary when serving the emperor and the Imperial Court.

sen.j: 明治政府は、1870年の平民苗字許容令、1872年（明治5年）の壬申戸籍編纂の二段階によって「氏（シ、うじ）＝姓（セイ、本姓）＝苗字＝名字」の一元化を成し遂げ、旧来の氏（ウヂ）・姓（カバネ）を公称することを自ら廃止したため、事実上、「藤原」などの旧来の氏（ウヂ）・「朝臣」などの姓（カバネ）は、その役割を完全に終えた。
sen.e: The use of traditional uji including 'Fujiwara' and kabane including 'ason' was banned and finished its role when the Meiji Government was able to unify the 'uji = family name' by issuing the order to allow all commoners to have family names in 1870 and the compilation of Jinshin-koseki (family registries in Jinshin) in 1872.
sen.cmt: 姓（セイ、本姓）＝苗字＝名字はfamily nameと訳しました。
sen.e: The use of traditional uji including 'Fujiwara' and kabane including 'ason' was banned and finished its role when the Meiji Government was able to unify the 'uji = family name' by issuing the order to allow all commoners to have family names in 1870 and the compilation of Jinshin-koseki (family registries in Jinshin) in 1872.

sen.j: この壬申戸籍以後、旧来の姓（カバネ）は、それと一体化していた旧来の氏（ウヂ）とともに、法的根拠をもって一本化された「氏（シ、うじ）＝姓（セイ、本姓）＝苗字＝名字」に完全に取って代わられることとなる。
sen.e: Since the Jinshin-koseki, the traditional kabane as well as uji were replaced with 'uji = family name' due to a legal basis.

sen.j: この新たな氏姓制度が日本国民全員に確立したのは、1875年（明治8年）の平民苗字必称令によってである。
sen.e: This new name system was carried out by all Japanese citizens when the order issued in 1875 made it mandatory to have a family.
This new name system was established among all Japanese citizens when the order issued in 1875 made it mandatory for all commoners to have family names.
